html.p: The following is a summary of the reading from the textbook to give you an idea of what is expected to know before coming to class. It does not replace reading the textbook.

Dielectric materials are insulators. Unlike metals they do not have free charges to move and conduct electricity when an electric field is applied. Instead of free charges, dielectrics have (or form) electric dipoles that do not move around much, but which are able to rotate and line up with an applied electric field. It is by these dipoles that dielectrics and electric fields interact.

There are solids that have built-in dipole moments and permanent electric fields. By analogy to magnets, these substances are called electrets. Quartz is a naturally occurring electret. Many electrets are manufactured from synthetic polymers. Teflon is an example.

Most dielelctric materials are not electrets; they do not contain intrinsic dipole moments. However, applying an electric field to a dielectric will cause dipoles to form in it. We say that the electric field “polarizes" the dielectric. An electric field exerts forces on a dielectric by interacting with its dipoles whether they are intrinsic or induced.

Dipoles in a dielectric have their own electric fields, and when aligned by an external field, these have a non-zero component in the direction opposite to that of the external field; they reduce field intensity in the space near them. This property of dielectrics is used to increase the capacitance of capacitors.

For many substances in electric fields that are not too large, the amount of dipole moment per unit volume is proportional to the applied electric field [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}[/mathjaxinline].
